question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to analyze specific musical features within songs
2. How to situate music within historical contexts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Musical contextualization, sonic elements of ethnicity, music as modernization

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Critical listening skills, especially for listening to pop music and music with lyrics, genres that I'm less familiar with analyzing
2. Developing a framework for understanding how (pop) music can reflect its social, cultural, and political context
3. Developing a foundational knowledge of key musical movements in the history of Asian and Asian American pop music, from Shanghai's shidaiqu to K-pop

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning how to analyze music with historical contexts, appreciating cultures in regards to music, and also developing the thinking of analyzing lyrics, transnationalism, and political music.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Different domains of asian and asian American music; foundational music theories that help to analyze different cultural backgrounds of different music genre; the link between asian music and asian modernity.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I particularly enjoyed any time we had practical learning experiences like karaoke, for instance. I also liked being able to do my own research and learn more about the topics that we learned in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor gave many opportunities for class discussion to keep us engaged in the lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the course was very discussion based. Professor Wang is an incredible listener, and provides positive insights on every discussion point brought up which I think tremendously helped the class engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was awesome! Emily's enthusiasm for the class and the material is evident and contagious. She was an incredibly approachable, flexible, and caring professor and created an environment where it felt like we were really able to think critically while also having fun in a low-stakes environment. The course's selected topics and the sequence in which these topics were presented were logical and coherent. I appreciated that Emily took the time to contextualize each new topic we discussed within the scope of what we had learned thus far. Topics were well-connected and referenced each other, which gave me a deeper appreciation for the course's ethnomusicological lens and each of the individual musics. Emily did a fantastic job of fostering a friendly and supportive class environment. Despite the larger class size, it felt like we were able to have discussions, share ideas, and get to know each other's ways of thinking. Emily also seemed genuinely interested in learning from us, fostering a non-hierarchical classroom environment (versus one where the professor clearly presents as the all-knowing expert uninterested in students' insights) that I think greatly encouraged students' independent thinking. Karaoke was a lot of fun and also helped build camaraderie among the class. I think all of the assignments were meaningful and useful while also leaving plenty of room for our own thinking and creativity (e.g. 3 you pick listening journals and a very open-ended final project). Course assignments were structured in a way that leaves options and appeals to a diversity of strengths and weaknesses (e.g. appealing to those who prefer test-taking vs. essay-writing and to those who prefer independent vs group work). Most of all, this class was fun! It's such a relief to have a class that is genuinely fun, where the professor is also excited to just have fun while still learning a lot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how much music we had to listen to. The listening reflection/listening journal was really fun, because it's pretty informal but still requires a level of understanding of musicology concepts. Final project is fun and I like Prof Wang's openness to all sorts of projects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Great learning environment! very interactive class sessions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Specifically learning about the historical contexts of different genres of music allowed me to view them differently and appreciate them more.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class approached sociological concepts through the lens of music.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course topic is super interesting, and the selection of music offers something that everyone can relate to or develop an interest in. Everyone in the class was generally very engaged, knowledgeable, and interested in the discussion. Most students had some proficiency in at least one East Asian language and experience with music, which made for exciting discussions. The class embraced students' personal interests. A focus on fun and constructive feedback made for a stimulating and positive learning environment.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked how I could relate many of the experiences we learned about in the content to myself and my own history. & hearing about my peers' own life experiences. I recall a classmate delivering some great insight into the K-pop industry, because she used to work as a choreographer in the industry! So cool to meet these people. Glad that they're 50/50 split between AADS/music majors and STEM majors (so many chems...). I liked discussing transnationalism throughout time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: a lot of the cultural backgrounds of the music really prompts thinking -- cross-disciplinary discussions happen a lot especially with political philosophy, history, and economics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is such a fun course, and you will definitely leave seeing music in a different way. You learn about different genres of music in different geographical locations, which allow you to draw parallels and make comparisons. I feel more in touch with my culture after taking this class, and I would recommend anyone interested in Asian studies or music to take it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course approaches various East Asian musical genres through the lenses of society and modernity. The class content is engaging and the workload isn't overbearing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I recommend

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take any class taught by Emily!!! If you see she's teaching a class, drop whatever you're doing and enroll. You will learn a ton but also have so much fun along the way...and also enjoy some tasty treats :). Best class ever!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You need to engage very actively with the content, your classmates, and Prof Wang. Be willing to listen to lots of different musics. No prior knowledge required! Just vibes! Personal relationship to course topic helps if you want to understand yourself better, but definitely not required.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it -- no matter if you are Asian or speak any Asian language. From the modern pop music in Asia (well, East Asia to be more exact) and Asian America, you actually learn tremendously about the historical reason behind why certain music sounds like a certain way coming from these countries and cultures, and it's a methodology extremely applicable to analyzing the music of other geographies -- we do a lot of cross cultural analysis in music beyond just Asian music as well.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In general, was an incredible introduction to historical thinking. First, Professor Cheung-Miaw helped us develop the skill of how to take individual accounts and weave stories or high level ideas. Second, I learned how to analyze primary sources effectively in broader contexts. And, finally, I improved on my ability to have historical discussions with my classmates through a lot of pair sharing.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The most useful skill I've improved is probably gathering and organizing the primary sources I found in my research.
Then, a throughout picture of Asian American history is very useful in my future research field of family history in Asia during warfare.
Finally, the class discussion though less significant to me compared to previous ones, still manages to help me bridge the gap between me as a transfer student and those who stay at Duke.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Most broadly, I learned how to examine key themes and ideas around not just Asian American history, but ways in which things like story-making/telling, identity, and relationalities can be analyzed and questioned through the lens of Asian American history. I also learned a lot about different events in Asian American history from the perspectives of a variety of sources, and how to put readings in conversation with each other. I really engaged with questioning in this class, in the sense of being critical about aspects of Asian American history that I assumed coming into the class, or how primary sources raised questions about our knowledge, or how to contend with contentions, ambiguities, and uncertainty in the story of Asian Americans over time.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: i learned the extent to which asian american psychology is intersectional--racial identity, gender/sexual identity, culture, mental health, and social stereotyping all affect each other (it's all a bit overwhelming). i also read interesting research papers that approached asian american identity development and mental health through an empirical perspective. the course guest speakers offered valuable insights into their respective academic research and clinical practices as well, which informed my understanding of certain aspects of asian american mental health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: theoretical knowledge about asian american psychology and history, particularly in thinking about the various avenues in which healthcare has systemically failed asian/americans (especially the intersectionally marginalised). I also learned a lot about asian/american psych's future directions, and thinking about how we provide care at various levels — policy, clinical and individual. also appreciated the skills involved in social science research and literature review.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The rooted ways that race impacts someone's experience with the medical field.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned to look at situations from multiple perspectives 
2) I learned to question why our systems are structured the way they are
3) I learned how to analyze different sources

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned new ways of viewing the world and combatting bias.
1) The effect of racism and disease narratives on the world in the past and present.
2) The way disease has been used as a weapon.
3) How to discuss bias while avoiding bias.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the world around me and specifically understand drivers of conflict and violence through the lense of marginalized populations such as queer communities, women, those of different ethnicities and races, immigrants, and more. In addition, learning how to read dense texts, ethnographies, and articles was a big part of the course, and I learned how to digest, understand, and analyse these texts as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the history of racialized and gendered medicine. I also learned how to evaluate medical/scientific interventions from a racially-conscious perspective and learned how to read texts better. Many of the people in the class are interested in pursuing healthcare professions so I think this class is particularly relevant and useful for us to critically evaluate the healthcare system and the how medicine has advanced through the expense of marginalized groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understood how historical context and biopolitics contribute to modern healthcare implementations for all groups who don't fit the standard cis, white, male body type. Along with this, I learned about who the actors vs. the subjects were in many cases, and how racism is inherent in many medical practices we pursue today. (For example, I honestly had NO idea that black women slaves were the unwilling subjects who gave us the practice of gynecology we have today.) I also learned how to digest large readings and get the main takeaways as we discussed them during class. As a cis white woman, I do want to mention how I came into this class not having a ton of background on these subjects and I now have learned so much that I will apply in the medical field - like taking into account the history of practices, understanding how livelihoods and backgrounds should be considered, and understanding how my own biases could impact my work on any individual.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in seminar/discussion based learning. The class is also reading heavy (~150 pages a week), but it only met once so it was doable. I learned a lot about colonial legacies in healthcare

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into the feasibility and ethical responsibilities in conducting ethnographic research/ the obligations you have when discussing a group's history, specifics about the creation of medical specialties and the system of public health in the US overall, and a troubling of the solutions I had previously devised for how to fix the US healthcare system.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the one book a week format. It was a lot of material but that allowed for a lot of depth and breadth, which I think is essential for these types of rooted and sensitive topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Rogers is an incredible human being who has a deep passion for global health and anthropology and other social science studies as well. Writing on the board to elucidate certain concepts that came about in our discussions to sharing stories of authors or other professors she interacted with, and even bringing current events into histories we were learning about facilitated my learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the seminar, discussion-based nature of the class. I also really enjoyed the student-led discussions because it helps students engage more deeply in the text, especially those who are leading the discussion. I also like the fact that it was longer (2.5 hrs) and once a week because you really need that amount of uninterrupted time to engage in such heavy texts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was the first time this class was taught, and while there were some bumps in the road, the professor did an AMAZING job with getting us to hear a diverse range of case studies and racial perspectives that allowed us to dive deep and "get real" with the concepts at play. This class felt pretty linear in the ways you'd want a class to be linear - like having a great direction with the texts we were made to read each week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors were very engaged with the class and were always available to answer our questions. I liked that a lot of this class was group work and I liked when different groups led discussions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Grading is super fair and reasonable and I also really enjoyed the low-stakes weekly essays which gave us creative freedom to explore/touch upon topics of the week more in-depth.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned more about the history of Chinatowns throughout the world throughout a mapping Chinatown project.
I learned how to conduct a basic ethnography of a local restaurant.
I learned how to embody the role of an activist/lawyer through the Chinatown game.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course changed my perspective on and deepened my insight into Chinese diaspora and Chinese American history. It also introduced new ways of analyzing immigrant histories and contemporary Chinese American sentiment, media coverage, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the cultural myths, and tropes, and history surrounding Asian identity around the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the history of Chinatowns as well as the many players and factions within a Chinatown that play a role in its functioning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history of Chinatowns, understood their role in local community and their global implications, and analyzed different components of them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at the historical context of Chinatowns in order to see how and why they exist
I learned that Chinatown is more than a fixed place in space that serves simply as a material existence
I learned how to call into question what it means to be "Chinese" and what constitutes for identity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Not only was the content we learned very rich, learning about the history of Chinese immigration (paper sons, wives) and how Chinese communities formed in America, we also learned how to critically engage with the sources we read, to think about whose stories get told in what manner. Who gets excluded, and why?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to network, the different dimensions of the chinese diasporic experience, how to interact with the neighboring communities

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: the nuances of chinatown communities, the various facets of these communities and our perspectives on them, and the intermingling of the chinese people and other groups

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading comprehension, critical analysis, synthesizing multiple view points

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

3. Writing food ethnographies

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: History of Chinatowns, power interactions that affect Chinatowns, Chinese diaspora

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to construct Chinese diaspora; How does food and food chain tells a historical story of Chinatown and its community; How does demographic and spatial factors construct Chinatowns

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to make a ethnography

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning about histories of Chinatowns, evaluating history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about flows of Chinese migration not just to the US, but also to Southeast Asia, and also other cities, including in Latin America, particularly through our first Chinatown assignment. Learned about different perspectives on Chinatowns from its residents (e.g. women, blue-collar and white-collar workers, recent and past immigrants, students). Considered methodologies of acquiring histories of marginalized populations and how in turn shapes our understanding of such populations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First and foremost, I learned about Chinatowns. There was a Chinatown in the city I grew up in, and I went every so often, but I never thought about its history much. I think the overall history of Chinese immigration was also something I learned. However, I enjoyed that we did not learn about Chinatowns as an individual idea, but rather as a continuous place of growing and transference of culture and knowledge, maintaining a connection with China and places all over the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about chinatowns as interconnected communities, analyizing immigrant patterns, contexts of that in relation to class, gender, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me a lot of new ways to think about the Chinese diaspora in general. For example, I learned about the history of Chinese immigration to America and the various issues and goings-on that were common in early Chinatowns. I also learned about more ways to examine "contemporary" topics such as interracial romance, higher education, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Taking a cultural history approach to understanding a dynamic community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of the best courses I have taken at Duke! I learned all about the patterns of migration, whether one has the ability to opt out of identity, and how political events shape perceptions of identity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about new frameworks in which to view past events, and learned about a whole new context behind Chinatowns and the emigration of early Chinese settlers to the US that I never considered before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the history of chinatowns, i learned how to draw deep insights from information i learned, also it was great to be able to read complicated scholarly articles and see what connections i can draw.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the historical foundations of Chinatowns and the Chinese diaspora, ranging from 11th century migration to Nanyang (the Chinese term for Southeast Asia), through the 1850s goldrushes in America and Australia that spurred large scale migration, up until the modern day impetus for migration away from China. We learned about the politics of "Chineseness" and what the political work of calling something a Chinatown means considering the derogatory connotations of the term historically. We also learned about the culinary scene of the Chinese diaspora and interrogated notions of "autheniticity", "hybridity", and "fusion."

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned more about immigrants' experiences on their journey to the United States.
2. I learned about how to write a food ethnography.
3. I learned about how to many different aspects of Chinatowns around the world.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There are weekly discussions and readings that are super interesting. As someone who doesn't typically enjoy the nature of role-playing games/debate style, I found it extremely fun and interesting, and I wouldn't let this dissuade anyone from taking the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment was excellent! I always felt comfortable participating in class. The class was incredibly interactive. I would keep all elements of the course. The presentation really helped me learn about the complex history of a Chinatown of our choice. The restaurant ethnography was a fantastic way of learning how to interview others and explore the culture of a space. The game was incredibly exciting, and it taught us how to put ourselves in the shoes of people with different interests at stake (e.g., businessmen, professors, activists, etc.). Professor Chow tried to facilitate events outside of class, like a Hotpot outing, which really helped build class community. She was an incredible lecturer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Chow was really engaging, and the assignments were very creative and stimulating. It forced you out of your comfort zone, connecting with the local Chinese community and stimulating what it would be like to live in a Chinatown with the end of the year game.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had town-hall style classes where Dr. Chow would give a presentation for the first 20-30 minutes (or longer depending on the day) and it would segue into more natural Q&A style things. We got to do our own research projects on specific Chinatowns, as well as write an ethnographic essay of a Chinese restaurant. The most fun part of class, as well as the most engaging was the three-week long Chinatown game where we all inhabited the roles of different stakeholders in LA Chinatown.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take this course! You learn so much about life and Asian American identity. You learn about the history of Chinatowns and how this history intersects with global identity. Professor Chow is incredibly nice, and the assignments are very fascinating. There are three major assignments: a presentation on the history of a Chinatown, a restaurant ethnography (interview a restaurant owner and write an ethnography), and a role-play game. The workload is very manageable, and Professor Chow really encourages you to think outside the box. This course was such a wonderful experience. Take it!!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the history of the term decolonization through the lens of decolonial movements and speakers. Sources we read/viewed ranged from extremely old to very recent postcolonial history. We learned about Decolonial movements globally, ideologies that made up these movements, and different ways to view the idea of decolonization as both a noun and a verb.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) What exactly is decolonization?
2) What do criticisms of decolonization look like? Why are they problematic?
3) Where is the intersection between violence and decolonization

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I have learned is what does decolonization mean (or what can it mean), how colonialism and the process of decolonization can be a shared or universal experience, and has improved my research abilities for finding primary/secondary sources for a research paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Secondary source analysis
2. Primary source analysis
3. Cross cultural sensitivity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: decolonial methods, awareness of the ways colonization affects the world, imperialism, decolonial movements, primary source analysis, settler colonialism, how violence exists in other forms aside from physical

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think more critically and historically about current movements. A better idea of what decolonization means to today on turtle island. What role art plays in the culture of revolution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about how decolonization is defined in different parts of the world and how our colonized approach to learning, living, and being skews the way we interpret and understand decolonization on a deeper level.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I learned in this course were how to approach history from a decolonial perspective, how to view colonizing experiences in an anti-imperial and anti-capitalist context, and also how to consider the relationships between different social justice movements and decolonization.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Before this class, I did not have an in-depth understanding of decolonization. However, after taking this course, I have a better grasp of how decolonization as a movement and thought has evolved from thinkers like Fanon, Said, and Cesaire to more contemporary scholars like Mohanty, Tapalde, and Tuck and Yang; the importance of centering indigenous voices in decolonization; and primary source analysis. All in all, I have more questions than answers, but I think that's exactly the point of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Writing a research paper starting from primary sources
2. Specific histories of decolonization in Africa and Asia
3. International organizing in the 20th century

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do not hesitate to take this course! Although the readings can be lengthy and hard to read at times, this course will fundamentally change the way you think about decolonization and how you think about your positionality in this world and the futurity and visions of a better world.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a solid introductory course to the history of decolonization and decolonial theory. Don't expect a deep dive into or close reading of particular texts, but you will get a good picture of decolonization in the 20th century (and a bit of more contemporary events/theory).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading academic works related to gender studies, synthesizing different types of sources (academic papers, podcasts, videos, etc.) while having discussions, how the concept of intimacy is present in so many spheres from relationships to communities to the nation and state

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the vast potential of intimacy, how intimacy relates to the nation state, and the tools we might use to guide our intimacies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: what is intimacy and how it is constructed through systematic institutions; how can we use intimacy as a potential force of change in the context of decolonization/power construct.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that questioning, wondering, and challenging stated beliefs are meaningful and valuable ways to think about complex/nuanced topics. I also learned how to combine and differentiate my thoughts from personal experience and identity from those that originate from more formal academic papers. This class also changed my perception of how I can contribute to group seminars in smaller groups vs larger classes, as well as synchronously vs asynchronously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned about different ways to think about intimacy theoretically
- I learned one of the three skills offered from our final project
- I learned how to better communicate during class discussions when I may not be super comfortable with the topic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest "knowledge" takeaway from this class was the ability to think about something abstract but ever-present in our lives that seems elusive and undefinable and to give it life. I think unlike some other classes that seek "productive" skills like coding this class allowed me to learn a more life-relevant skill of articulating complex ideas with interconnected and intricate histories. The first thing I learned was about history, it was the backbone of understanding the course's definitions of intimacy. The second thing I learned was about the ways that novels and films reveal layers of intimacy that feel relevant to life. The final thing I learned was about ways to interact more deeply with my classmates.

conceptually thinking about intimacy in new ways

- how to be a better writer (what am i trying to communicate here, how can i make taht clear,,,is this clear lol)

Practice taking in what works for you and your project and letting go of what doesn't. Feedback is great but at the end of the day it is your project.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be sure to have access to primary sources from your field. Students who lacked access to primary sources did not progress as well with their papers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be all-in. Challenge yourself, speak up, and embrace vulnerability of critique -- the greatest learning is from the discussions and peer interactions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I developed a critical understanding of how the Pacific is imagined beyond geographic borders—through lenses like trauma, techno-orientalism, environmental collapse, and posthumanism.
-I strengthened my ability to closely read and interpret film and literature through weekly paragraph reflections and analytical essays. This course helped me shift from surface-level observation to deep cultural critique.
-I learned to conduct archival and secondary research for literary analysis, particularly through our Rubenstein Library visit and the library session on sourcing academic criticism for our final paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My media literacy definitely improved greatly. I also learned a lot about engaging actively in discussion about media and literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analysis of the post-apocalypse in Asian-American literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the Pacific Ocean through history and post-apocalyptic fiction. I engaged with impressive and mind expanding media I would not have otherwise encountered and challenged my perspectives on things I was already familar with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really pushed my critical thinking and textual analysis skills. We analyzed films and texts that I would not have thought to analyze on my own, and it really allowed me to see how these skills in analysis I am developing can be applied to a range of media. This course also reframed my understanding of anime, sci-fi, and fiction. It was really interesting examining primary texts and films that I have watched for fun in a different way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe that this course was very valuable in helping develop as both a writer and in analysis of a variety of media forms. I became more able to synthesize ideas about texts into conversation to more deeply engage with symbols, themes and character concepts, developed in creating arguable theses for papers, and also have gained important research skills relating to secondary sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to examine films through a symbolic and literary lens. I also learned how to close read novels/long prose to identify symbolism and deeper meanings beneath the text. Finally, I would say the most important skill I learned was learning to write using new theories and ideas that we went over and integrating those into my own writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Out of all the courses I've taken in my four years at this school, this one has helped me the most, especially in developing my critical thinking and writing skills. It taught me how to draw meaningful connections across various forms of media, from movies and books to short stories and anime. One specific thing I’ve learned is how to think critically in ways I hadn’t before. Now, when I read a book or watch a movie, I find myself looking for deeper connections. Discussing these ideas in class with my peers has also opened me up to new perspectives, helping me understand the text or media in ways I wouldn’t have on my own. I also became a better writer, being able to incorporate multiple resources, and flesh out strong arguments that I can write a paper about. And I now have a very strong understanding of the meaning of "the post apocalypse".

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Koo structured the course in a way that balanced thematic progression with skill development. Weekly paragraphs encouraged consistent engagement, while short essays scaffolded our final paper. Her clear prompts, regular check-ins, and individualized support—especially during office hours and workshops—made a huge difference. The flexibility to explore our interests (e.g., choosing our own topics/texts for essays) fostered genuine curiosity and intellectual risk-taking. I would keep the "Paragraph of the Week" assignments and the final paper workshops.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class offered a truly unique lens on apocalyptic narratives by centering Pacific and diasporic experiences. I had never considered how deeply the legacy of war, colonization, and ecological destruction shaped speculative fiction. Discussions were complex and rich, especially when tying in real-world histories like Gwangju, Fukushima, and the Vietnam War. Professor Koo’s guiding questions always pushed us beyond the obvious.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned more about the history of Chinatowns throughout the world throughout a mapping Chinatown project.
I learned how to conduct a basic ethnography of a local restaurant.
I learned how to embody the role of an activist/lawyer through the Chinatown game.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course changed my perspective on and deepened my insight into Chinese diaspora and Chinese American history. It also introduced new ways of analyzing immigrant histories and contemporary Chinese American sentiment, media coverage, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the cultural myths, and tropes, and history surrounding Asian identity around the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the history of Chinatowns as well as the many players and factions within a Chinatown that play a role in its functioning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history of Chinatowns, understood their role in local community and their global implications, and analyzed different components of them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at the historical context of Chinatowns in order to see how and why they exist
I learned that Chinatown is more than a fixed place in space that serves simply as a material existence
I learned how to call into question what it means to be "Chinese" and what constitutes for identity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Not only was the content we learned very rich, learning about the history of Chinese immigration (paper sons, wives) and how Chinese communities formed in America, we also learned how to critically engage with the sources we read, to think about whose stories get told in what manner. Who gets excluded, and why?

response_text: the nuances of chinatown communities, the various facets of these communities and our perspectives on them, and the intermingling of the chinese people and other groups

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about flows of Chinese migration not just to the US, but also to Southeast Asia, and also other cities, including in Latin America, particularly through our first Chinatown assignment. Learned about different perspectives on Chinatowns from its residents (e.g. women, blue-collar and white-collar workers, recent and past immigrants, students). Considered methodologies of acquiring histories of marginalized populations and how in turn shapes our understanding of such populations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First and foremost, I learned about Chinatowns. There was a Chinatown in the city I grew up in, and I went every so often, but I never thought about its history much. I think the overall history of Chinese immigration was also something I learned. However, I enjoyed that we did not learn about Chinatowns as an individual idea, but rather as a continuous place of growing and transference of culture and knowledge, maintaining a connection with China and places all over the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about chinatowns as interconnected communities, analyizing immigrant patterns, contexts of that in relation to class, gender, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me a lot of new ways to think about the Chinese diaspora in general. For example, I learned about the history of Chinese immigration to America and the various issues and goings-on that were common in early Chinatowns. I also learned about more ways to examine "contemporary" topics such as interracial romance, higher education, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of the best courses I have taken at Duke! I learned all about the patterns of migration, whether one has the ability to opt out of identity, and how political events shape perceptions of identity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about new frameworks in which to view past events, and learned about a whole new context behind Chinatowns and the emigration of early Chinese settlers to the US that I never considered before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the history of chinatowns, i learned how to draw deep insights from information i learned, also it was great to be able to read complicated scholarly articles and see what connections i can draw.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the historical foundations of Chinatowns and the Chinese diaspora, ranging from 11th century migration to Nanyang (the Chinese term for Southeast Asia), through the 1850s goldrushes in America and Australia that spurred large scale migration, up until the modern day impetus for migration away from China. We learned about the politics of "Chineseness" and what the political work of calling something a Chinatown means considering the derogatory connotations of the term historically. We also learned about the culinary scene of the Chinese diaspora and interrogated notions of "autheniticity", "hybridity", and "fusion."

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned more about immigrants' experiences on their journey to the United States.
2. I learned about how to write a food ethnography.
3. I learned about how to many different aspects of Chinatowns around the world.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There are weekly discussions and readings that are super interesting. In addition, there is a food and chinatown ethnography project that let you dive deep into a Chinatown and restaurant, and lastly there is a roleplaying-type game. As someone who doesn't typically enjoy the nature of role-playing games/debate style, I found it extremely fun and interesting, and I wouldn't let this dissuade anyone from taking the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment was excellent! I always felt comfortable participating in class. The class was incredibly interactive. I would keep all elements of the course. The presentation really helped me learn about the complex history of a Chinatown of our choice. The restaurant ethnography was a fantastic way of learning how to interview others and explore the culture of a space. The game was incredibly exciting, and it taught us how to put ourselves in the shoes of people with different interests at stake (e.g., businessmen, professors, activists, etc.). Professor Chow tried to facilitate events outside of class, like a Hotpot outing, which really helped build class community. She was an incredible lecturer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: We had town-hall style classes where Dr. Chow would give a presentation for the first 20-30 minutes (or longer depending on the day) and it would segue into more natural Q&A style things. We got to do our own research projects on specific Chinatowns, as well as write an ethnographic essay of a Chinese restaurant. The most fun part of class, as well as the most engaging was the three-week long Chinatown game where we all inhabited the roles of different stakeholders in LA Chinatown.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take this course! You learn so much about life and Asian American identity. You learn about the history of Chinatowns and how this history intersects with global identity. Professor Chow is incredibly nice, and the assignments are very fascinating. There are three major assignments: a presentation on the history of a Chinatown, a restaurant ethnography (interview a restaurant owner and write an ethnography), and a role-play game. The workload is very manageable, and Professor Chow really encourages you to think outside the box. This course was such a wonderful experience. Take it!!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed more intellectual capacity on critical thinking regarding topics of colonialism, neoliberalism, and violence. The instructor provides a good connection between theoretical materials and analysis of specific cases. First of all, I was able to reflect on the epistemological perception of Cold War and the manifestation of its polarization regarding historical narratives. Second, I was able to develop a critical understanding of violence in the context of de-colonization and the limitations of nation-states. Third, the instructor provides diverse interaction with other urgent political issues and events, enabling us to think beyond the scope of our reading materials.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about U.S. - Asia transpacific relations through lenses of race, gender, and colonialism. I specifically learned about historically ignored cases of Korean soldiers fighting in Japanese forces in World War II, U.S. camp towns in Korea, and the Japanese World War II comfort women, as well as lenses of orientalism and settler colonialism as they pertain to Palestine and the United States.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course has significantly enhanced my understanding of colonialism and anti-Asian discrimination, particularly in the context of U.S.-Asia power dynamics. I learned valuable frameworks for analyzing historical and contemporary power relationships between these regions. Additionally, I gained practical skills in utilizing library resources effectively for research on these topics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The reading list is more recent and up-to-date compared to the really canonical stuff, but you can find it boring or hard to comprehend if you have not received prior training on basic postcolonial and postmodern theories. The classes are mainly composed of students' discussions with comments from the instructor, so I would say what you can get from the course greatly relies on your peers' contributions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a good class, but the most of what you get out of the class is the effort you put into the readings and what you bring to the discussion. If others don’t participate in the seminar, that can really detract from your experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned new ways of viewing the world and combatting bias.
1) The effect of racism and disease narratives on the world in the past and present.
2) The way disease has been used as a weapon.
3) How to discuss bias while avoiding bias.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the world around me and specifically understand drivers of conflict and violence through the lense of marginalized populations such as queer communities, women, those of different ethnicities and races, immigrants, and more. In addition, learning how to read dense texts, ethnographies, and articles was a big part of the course, and I learned how to digest, understand, and analyse these texts as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the history of racialized and gendered medicine. I also learned how to evaluate medical/scientific interventions from a racially-conscious perspective and learned how to read texts better. Many of the people in the class are interested in pursuing healthcare professions so I think this class is particularly relevant and useful for us to critically evaluate the healthcare system and the how medicine has advanced through the expense of marginalized groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understood how historical context and biopolitics contribute to modern healthcare implementations for all groups who don't fit the standard cis, white, male body type. Along with this, I learned about who the actors vs. the subjects were in many cases, and how racism is inherent in many medical practices we pursue today. (For example, I honestly had NO idea that black women slaves were the unwilling subjects who gave us the practice of gynecology we have today.) I also learned how to digest large readings and get the main takeaways as we discussed them during class. As a cis white woman, I do want to mention how I came into this class not having a ton of background on these subjects and I now have learned so much that I will apply in the medical field - like taking into account the history of practices, understanding how livelihoods and backgrounds should be considered, and understanding how my own biases could impact my work on any individual.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in seminar/discussion based learning. The class is also reading heavy (~150 pages a week), but it only met once so it was doable. I learned a lot about colonial legacies in healthcare

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into the feasibility and ethical responsibilities in conducting ethnographic research/ the obligations you have when discussing a group's history, specifics about the creation of medical specialties and the system of public health in the US overall, and a troubling of the solutions I had previously devised for how to fix the US healthcare system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I developed a critical understanding of how the Pacific is imagined beyond geographic borders—through lenses like trauma, techno-orientalism, environmental collapse, and posthumanism.
-I strengthened my ability to closely read and interpret film and literature through weekly paragraph reflections and analytical essays. This course helped me shift from surface-level observation to deep cultural critique.
-I learned to conduct archival and secondary research for literary analysis, particularly through our Rubenstein Library visit and the library session on sourcing academic criticism for our final paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My media literacy definitely improved greatly. I also learned a lot about engaging actively in discussion about media and literature.

response_text: Analysis of the post-apocalypse in Asian-American literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the Pacific Ocean through history and post-apocalyptic fiction. I engaged with impressive and mind expanding media I would not have otherwise encountered and challenged my perspectives on things I was already familar with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really pushed my critical thinking and textual analysis skills. We analyzed films and texts that I would not have thought to analyze on my own, and it really allowed me to see how these skills in analysis I am developing can be applied to a range of media. This course also reframed my understanding of anime, sci-fi, and fiction. It was really interesting examining primary texts and films that I have watched for fun in a different way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe that this course was very valuable in helping develop as both a writer and in analysis of a variety of media forms. I became more able to synthesize ideas about texts into conversation to more deeply engage with symbols, themes and character concepts, developed in creating arguable theses for papers, and also have gained important research skills relating to secondary sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to examine films through a symbolic and literary lens. I also learned how to close read novels/long prose to identify symbolism and deeper meanings beneath the text. Finally, I would say the most important skill I learned was learning to write using new theories and ideas that we went over and integrating those into my own writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Out of all the courses I've taken in my four years at this school, this one has helped me the most, especially in developing my critical thinking and writing skills. It taught me how to draw meaningful connections across various forms of media, from movies and books to short stories and anime. One specific thing I’ve learned is how to think critically in ways I hadn’t before. Now, when I read a book or watch a movie, I find myself looking for deeper connections. Discussing these ideas in class with my peers has also opened me up to new perspectives, helping me understand the text or media in ways I wouldn’t have on my own. I also became a better writer, being able to incorporate multiple resources, and flesh out strong arguments that I can write a paper about. And I now have a very strong understanding of the meaning of "the post apocalypse".

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Koo structured the course in a way that balanced thematic progression with skill development. Weekly paragraphs encouraged consistent engagement, while short essays scaffolded our final paper. Her clear prompts, regular check-ins, and individualized support—especially during office hours and workshops—made a huge difference. The flexibility to explore our interests (e.g., choosing our own topics/texts for essays) fostered genuine curiosity and intellectual risk-taking. I would keep the "Paragraph of the Week" assignments and the final paper workshops.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class offered a truly unique lens on apocalyptic narratives by centering Pacific and diasporic experiences. I had never considered how deeply the legacy of war, colonization, and ecological destruction shaped speculative fiction. Discussions were complex and rich, especially when tying in real-world histories like Gwangju, Fukushima, and the Vietnam War. Professor Koo’s guiding questions always pushed us beyond the obvious.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest "knowledge" takeaway from this class was the ability to think about something abstract but ever-present in our lives that seems elusive and undefinable and to give it life. I think unlike some other classes that seek "productive" skills like coding this class allowed me to learn a more life-relevant skill of articulating complex ideas with interconnected and intricate histories. The first thing I learned was about history, it was the backbone of understanding the course's definitions of intimacy. The second thing I learned was about the ways that novels and films reveal layers of intimacy that feel relevant to life. The final thing I learned was about ways to interact more deeply with my classmates.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In general, was an incredible introduction to historical thinking. First, Professor Cheung-Miaw helped us develop the skill of how to take individual accounts and weave stories or high level ideas. Second, I learned how to analyze primary sources effectively in broader contexts. And, finally, I improved on my ability to have historical discussions with my classmates through a lot of pair sharing.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.

response_text:
The most useful skill I've improved is probably gathering and organizing the primary sources I found in my research.
Then, a throughout picture of Asian American history is very useful in my future research field of family history in Asia during warfare.
Finally, the class discussion though less significant to me compared to previous ones, still manages to help me bridge the gap between me as a transfer student and those who stay at Duke.

course: HISTORY-198-01 : INTRO TO ASIAN AMERICAN HIST.HISTORY-198-01.AADS-198-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Most broadly, I learned how to examine key themes and ideas around not just Asian American history, but ways in which things like story-making/telling, identity, and relationalities can be analyzed and questioned through the lens of Asian American history. I also learned a lot about different events in Asian American history from the perspectives of a variety of sources, and how to put readings in conversation with each other. I really engaged with questioning in this class, in the sense of being critical about aspects of Asian American history that I assumed coming into the class, or how primary sources raised questions about our knowledge, or how to contend with contentions, ambiguities, and uncertainty in the story of Asian Americans over time.
